newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai soybean futures end mixed in slow trade.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai soybean futures end mixed in slow trade.

text.p: Shanghai soybean futures ended mixed in slow trade on Monday with many investors leaving the dull market and moving their money to more active areas, traders said.
The most actively traded September 1997 contract ended at 3,158 yuan ($380) per tonne, rising five yuan. It opened at an intraday low of 3,150 yuan and hit a high of 3,160 yuan per tonne.
July did not trade, November fell three to 3,162, the January 1998 contract 22 to 3,118 and March rose five to 3,155.
Combined volume fell to 19,200 tonnes from 23,700 tonnes.
Soybeans opened mixed and moved around opening levels for most of the session, traders said.
"Many investors moved their money into other active futures markets like the metals market as well as the domestic stock markets," one trader said.
"A lack of market-moving news made soybeans move in a very narrow range today," he added.
Traders said they expected soybeans to consolidate in the next few days.
